metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: JavaScript Variables
Variables are Containers for Storing Data
JavaScript Variables can be declared in 4 ways:
content.html: JavaScript Variables can be declared in 4 ways:

content.text: In this first example, x , y , and z are undeclared variables.
content.html: In this first example, x, y, and z are undeclared variables.

content.text: They are automatically declared when first used:
content.html: They are automatically declared when first used:

content.code_html:
x = 5;
y = 6;
z = x + y;

content.text: Note
It is considered good programming practice to always declare variables before use.
content.html: It is considered good programming practice to always declare variables before use.

content.text: From the examples you can guess:
content.html: From the examples you can guess:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
var x = 5;var y = 6;
var z = x + y;

content.code:
var x = 5;var y = 6;
var z = x + y;

syntax_highlighting.text:
var x = 5;var y = 6;
var z = x + y;

content.code_html:
var x = 5;
var y = 6;
var z = x + y;

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
var x = 5;var y = 6;
var z = x + y;

content.text: Note
The var keyword was used in all JavaScript code from 1995 to 2015.
content.html: The var keyword was used in all JavaScript code from 1995 to 2015.

content.text: The let and const keywords were added to JavaScript in 2015.
content.html: The let and const keywords were added to JavaScript in 2015.

content.text: The var keyword should only be used in code written for older browsers.
content.html: The var keyword should only be used in code written for older browsers.

content.code_html:
let x = 5;
let y = 6;
let z = x + y;

const x = 5;
const y = 6;
const z = x + y;

const price1 = 5;
const price2 = 6;
let total = price1 + price2;

content.text: The two variables price1 and price2 are declared with the const keyword.
content.html: The two variables price1 and price2 are declared with the const keyword.

content.text: These are constant values and cannot be changed.
content.html: These are constant values and cannot be changed.

content.text: The variable total is declared with the let keyword.
content.html: The variable total is declared with the let keyword.

content.text: The value total can be changed.
content.html: The value total can be changed.

content.text: When to Use var, let, or const?
1. Always declare variables
content.html: 1. Always declare variables

content.text: 2. Always use const if the value should not be changed
content.html: 2. Always use const if the value should not be changed

content.text: 3. Always use const if the type should not be changed (Arrays and Objects)
content.html: 3. Always use const if the type should not be changed (Arrays and Objects)

content.text: 4. Only use let if you can't use const
content.html: 4. Only use let if you can't use const

content.text: 5. Only use var if you MUST support old browsers.
content.html: 5. Only use var if you MUST support old browsers.

content.text: Just Like Algebra
Just like in algebra, variables hold values:
content.html: Just like in algebra, variables hold values:

content.code_html:
let x = 5;
let y = 6;

content.text: Just like in algebra, variables are used in expressions:
content.html: Just like in algebra, variables are used in expressions:

content.code_html: let z = x + y;

content.text: From the example above, you can guess that the total is calculated to be 11.
content.html: From the example above, you can guess that the total is calculated to be 11.

content.text: Note
Variables are containers for storing values.
content.html: Variables are containers for storing values.

content.text: JavaScript Identifiers
All JavaScript variables must be identified with unique names .
content.html: All JavaScript variables must be identified with unique names.

content.text: These unique names are called identifiers .
content.html: These unique names are called identifiers.

content.text: Identifiers can be short names (like x and y) or more descriptive names (age, sum, totalVolume).
content.html: Identifiers can be short names (like x and y) or more descriptive names (age, sum, totalVolume).

content.text: The general rules for constructing names for variables (unique identifiers) are:
content.html: The general rules for constructing names for variables (unique identifiers) are:

content.text: Note
JavaScript identifiers are case-sensitive.
content.html: JavaScript identifiers are case-sensitive.

content.text: The Assignment Operator
In JavaScript, the equal sign ( = ) is an "assignment" operator, not an "equal to" operator.
content.html: In JavaScript, the equal sign (=) is an "assignment" operator, not an "equal to" operator.

content.text: This is different from algebra. The following does not make sense in algebra:
content.html: This is different from algebra. The following does not make sense in algebra:

content.code_html: x = x + 5

content.text: In JavaScript, however, it makes perfect sense: it assigns the value of x + 5 to x.
content.html: In JavaScript, however, it makes perfect sense: it assigns the value of x + 5 to x.

content.text: (It calculates the value of x + 5 and puts the result into x. The value of x is incremented by 5.)
content.html: (It calculates the value of x + 5 and puts the result into x. The value of x is incremented by 5.)

content.text: Note
The "equal to" operator is written like == in JavaScript.
content.html: The "equal to" operator is written like == in JavaScript.

content.text: JavaScript Data Types
JavaScript variables can hold numbers like 100 and text values like "John Doe".
content.html: JavaScript variables can hold numbers like 100 and text values like "John Doe".

content.text: In programming, text values are called text strings.
content.html: In programming, text values are called text strings.

content.text: JavaScript can handle many types of data, but for now, just think of numbers and strings.
content.html: JavaScript can handle many types of data, but for now, just think of numbers and strings.

content.text: Strings are written inside double or single quotes. Numbers are written without quotes.
content.html: Strings are written inside double or single quotes. Numbers are written without quotes.

content.text: If you put a number in quotes, it will be treated as a text string.
content.html: If you put a number in quotes, it will be treated as a text string.

content.code_html:
const pi = 3.14;
let person = "John Doe";
let answer = 'Yes I am!';

content.text: Declaring a JavaScript Variable
Creating a variable in JavaScript is called "declaring" a variable.
content.html: Creating a variable in JavaScript is called "declaring" a variable.

content.text: You declare a JavaScript variable with the var or the let keyword:
content.html: You declare a JavaScript variable with the var or the let keyword:

content.code_html: var carName;

content.text: After the declaration, the variable has no value (technically it is undefined ).
content.html: After the declaration, the variable has no value (technically it is undefined).

content.text: To assign a value to the variable, use the equal sign:
content.html: To assign a value to the variable, use the equal sign:

content.code_html: carName = "Volvo";

content.text: You can also assign a value to the variable when you declare it:
content.html: You can also assign a value to the variable when you declare it:

content.code_html: let carName = "Volvo";

content.text: In the example below, we create a variable called carName and assign the value "Volvo" to it.
content.html: In the example below, we create a variable called carName and assign the value "Volvo" to it.

content.text: Then we "output" the value inside an HTML paragraph with id="demo":
content.html: Then we "output" the value inside an HTML paragraph with id="demo":

content.code_html:
<p id="demo"></p>

<script>
let carName = "Volvo";
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = carName;
</script>

content.text: Note
It's a good programming practice to declare all variables at the beginning of a script.
content.html: It's a good programming practice to declare all variables at the beginning of a script.

content.text: One Statement, Many Variables
You can declare many variables in one statement.
content.html: You can declare many variables in one statement.

content.text: Start the statement with let and separate the variables by comma :
content.html: Start the statement with let and separate the variables by comma:

content.code_html: let person = "John Doe", carName = "Volvo", price = 200;

content.text: A declaration can span multiple lines:
content.html: A declaration can span multiple lines:

content.code_html:
let person = "John Doe",
carName = "Volvo",
price = 200;

content.text: Value = undefined
In computer programs, variables are often declared without a value. The value can be something that has to be calculated, or something that will be provided later, like user input.
content.html: In computer programs, variables are often declared without a value. The value can be something that has to be calculated, or something that will be provided later, like user input.

content.text: A variable declared without a value will have the value undefined .
content.html: A variable declared without a value will have the value undefined.

content.text: The variable carName will have the value undefined after the execution of this statement:
content.html: The variable carName will have the value undefined after the execution of this statement:

content.code_html: let carName;

content.text: Re-Declaring JavaScript Variables
If you re-declare a JavaScript variable declared with var , it will not lose its value.
content.html: If you re-declare a JavaScript variable declared with var, it will not lose its value.

content.text: The variable carName will still have the value "Volvo" after the execution of these statements:
content.html: The variable carName will still have the value "Volvo" after the execution of these statements:

content.code_html:
var carName = "Volvo";
var carName;

content.text: Note
You cannot re-declare a variable declared with let or const .
content.html: You cannot re-declare a variable declared with let or const.

content.text: This will not work:
content.html: This will not work:

content.code_html:
let carName = "Volvo";
let carName;

content.text: JavaScript Arithmetic
As with algebra, you can do arithmetic with JavaScript variables, using operators like = and + :
content.html: As with algebra, you can do arithmetic with JavaScript variables, using operators like = and +:

content.code_html: let x = 5 + 2 + 3;

content.text: You can also add strings, but strings will be concatenated:
content.html: You can also add strings, but strings will be concatenated:

content.code_html: let x = "John" + " " + "Doe";

content.text: Also try this:
content.html: Also try this:

content.code_html: let x = "5" + 2 + 3;

content.text: Note
If you put a number in quotes, the rest of the numbers will be treated as strings, and concatenated.
content.html: If you put a number in quotes, the rest of the numbers will be treated as strings, and concatenated.

content.text: Now try this:
content.html: Now try this:

content.code_html: let x = 2 + 3 + "5";

content.text: JavaScript Dollar Sign $
Since JavaScript treats a dollar sign as a letter, identifiers containing $ are valid variable names:
content.html: Since JavaScript treats a dollar sign as a letter, identifiers containing $ are valid variable names:

content.code_html:
let $ = "Hello World";
let $$$ = 2;
let $myMoney = 5;

content.text: Using the dollar sign is not very common in JavaScript, but professional programmers often use it as an alias for the main function in a JavaScript library.
content.html: Using the dollar sign is not very common in JavaScript, but professional programmers often use it as an alias for the main function in a JavaScript library.

content.text: In the JavaScript library jQuery, for instance, the main function $ is used to select HTML elements. In jQuery $("p"); means "select all p elements".
content.html: In the JavaScript library jQuery, for instance, the main function $ is used to select HTML elements. In jQuery $("p"); means "select all p elements".

content.text: JavaScript Underscore (_)
Since JavaScript treats underscore as a letter, identifiers containing _ are valid variable names:
content.html: Since JavaScript treats underscore as a letter, identifiers containing _ are valid variable names:

content.code_html:
let _lastName = "Johnson";
let _x = 2;
let _100 = 5;

content.text: Using the underscore is not very common in JavaScript, but a convention among professional programmers is to use it as an alias for "private (hidden)" variables.
content.html: Using the underscore is not very common in JavaScript, but a convention among professional programmers is to use it as an alias for "private (hidden)" variables.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
What is NOT a correct syntax for declaring variables?
content.html: What is NOT a correct syntax for declaring variables?
